message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe, generalized abdominal pain, with significant vital sign abnormalities, suggests perforation. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy would present with pelvic pain and vaginal bleeding. Bowel obstruction would present with abdominal distension and vomiting, and colorectal cancer would cause more chronic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain with diffuse tenderness, guarding, and rebound, absent bowel sounds, and leukocytosis suggests an acute abdominal condition requiring urgent surgery. The most likely cause is perforation, possibly due to a gastric or duodenal ulcer in this patient with a history of chronic lower back pain and use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (ibuprofen). Ruptured ectopic pregnancy would cause lower abdominal pain localized to one side, and bowel obstruction would cause a more gradual onset of symptoms with constipation and vomiting. Colorectal cancer is unlikely in a patient of this age and with no family history of colon cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, distended abdomen, absent bowel sounds, and leukocytosis indicate a possible perforation of an abdominal organ. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy and bowel obstruction are possible causes of abdominal pain but they do not fit with the lack of bowel sounds and the diffuse tenderness. Colorectal cancer is unlikely to cause such sudden and severe pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, distended tympanic abdomen, diffuse tenderness, guarding, rebound, and absent bowel sounds all suggest that the most likely cause of the pain is perforation. The patient's medical history and physical examination do not provide any evidence to support the other options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe, generalized abdominal pain with a distended, tympanic abdomen, diffuse tenderness, guarding, and rebound, as well as absent bowel sounds and signs of shock, suggest a perforation. A ruptured ectopic pregnancy may cause severe abdominal pain, but typically presents with vaginal bleeding and a positive pregnancy test. Bowel obstruction may cause abdominal pain but typically presents with nausea, vomiting, and constipation. Colorectal cancer may present with abdominal pain, but is less likely to cause sudden onset and signs of shock.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe, generalized abdominal pain, distended tympanic abdomen, absent bowel sounds, guarding, and rebound suggests perforation. The patient does not have any symptoms suggestive of the other options such as vaginal bleeding or changes in bowel habits. The patient's chronic lower back pain and use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) increases the risk of gastrointestinal perforation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe, generalized abdominal pain with distended, tympanic abdomen with diffuse tenderness, guarding, and rebound, along with absent bowel sounds, suggests perforation. Options A and B might also cause severe abdominal pain, but the absence of bowel sounds and distended abdomen make perforation more likely. Option D is less likely based on the patient's age and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of sudden onset of severe, generalized abdominal pain, absent bowel sounds, and signs of peritonitis are most consistent with perforation. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy is less likely given her last menstrual period was only 2 weeks ago, and bowel obstruction would have bowel sounds present. Colorectal cancer is unlikely to present with such acute symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, distended tympanic abdomen with diffuse tenderness, and absent bowel sounds suggest perforation. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy can also cause severe abdominal pain but there is no reported vaginal bleeding. Bowel obstruction would have reported constipation, nausea, and vomiting. Colorectal cancer usually occurs in older patients and would not cause sudden onset of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe, generalized abdominal pain with distended, tympanic abdomen, diffuse tenderness, guarding, and rebound, along with absent bowel sounds and low blood pressure suggest that the most likely cause is perforation. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy, bowel obstruction, and colorectal cancer have different symptoms and signs.
